pageData.text: Students will collect water samples from local waterways and test them for factors that governments and scientists use to monitor the health of natural waterways.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Printed copy of DO percent saturation chart
Printed copies of Table 1, and Data Tables 1 and 2 (optional)
Aluminum foil
Stopwatch or timer
Household bleach
GPS or GPS-enabled phone (recommended)
Cooler with ice (optional)
Bucket/container for waste disposal in the field (optional)
Straightedge
Container that can hold 150 mL of water with a secure lid (the lid must be able to fasten tightly)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 40 minutes 
Activity 1: Sample Collection and Water Quality Tests Sample Collection – 5 minutes 
                 Coliform Bacteria Test – 10 minutes + 48 hours 
                 Dissolved Oxygen and Biological Oxygen Demand Test – 20 minutes + 5 days
                 Nitrate Test – 10 minutes
                 pH Test – 10 minutes
                 Phosphate Test – 10 minutes
                 Temperature Measurement – 5 minutes
Alternative Activities:
                 Calculating Dissolved Oxygen Percent Saturation – 10 minutes
                 Turbidity Test – 10 minutes

pageData.text: This lab requires the collection of water samples from up to 10 separate sites. Travel time is in addition to times listed below. Times listed below are also “per sample” times.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Quality of Surface Waters

text: Practice proper water sample collection techniques.
Conduct chemical and biological analyses of field water samples.
Assess the health of local aquatic environments.
Compare water test results to environmental standards.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Agricultural runoff of synthetic fertilizers and untreated human and animal waste increase the concentration of chemicals such as nitrogen and phosphorus in water systems, causing damage at high concentrations. Excess nitrates in particular pose a danger to human health. High levels of nitrates can enter the blood stream, binding with the hemoglobin in red blood cells to create methemoglobin. This molecule carries oxygen less efficiently than hemoglobin and so limits the amount of oxygen carried to cells and tissues.

Healthy adults can quickly reverse this reaction and restore function. Infants, who are much smaller and have developing systems, can develop methemoglobinemia or “blue baby syndrome”, which can be fatal. Without oxygen, these infants develop bluish-grey skin, as well as lethargy, diarrhea and vomiting.  Most cases of blue baby syndrome occur when infants drink baby formula made with water from a contaminated well. If caught early enough, the condition is easily reversed using the common lab reagent methylene blue; future relapses can be prevented by regularly checking the nitrate levels of any wells used for drinking water<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1Environmental Public Health Office of Drinking Water. (2016, July). Nitrate in drinking water. Washington State Department of Health. https://doh.wa.gov/sites/default/files/legacy/Documents/Pubs/331-214.pdf

pageData.desc: A well water pump from which hangs a bucket of water.
pageData.altText: A well water pump from which hangs a bucket of water.

pageData.text: Water is one of the most common and precious compounds on Earth. Water covers approximately 75% of Earth’s surface, but only 2.5% of this is freshwater—and only a small fraction of that 2.5% is accessible for use and consumption. We depend on a clean water supply for drinking, cleaning, sanitation, recreation, and manufacturing. Public health officials and biologists have developed tests that can be used to monitor the quality of natural waters and to locate sources (and potential sources) of water pollution. In this activity, you will collect samples from local waterways and test and evaluate water quality on the basis of several characteristics used by scientists to analyze natural waters.

pageData.subTitle: Nitrogen and Phosphorous
pageData.text: Water is an important agent for dissolving and transporting many <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> (essential compounds for life) through the environment. The growth of primary producers (and, by extension, all organisms throughout a food web) in any environment is limited by the availability of a particular resource. That resource can be physical, such as light or space, or it can be a nutrient.

In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. Most fertilizers contain nitrogen and phosphorus as water-soluble nitrates (NO<sub class='bodysubscript'>3–</sub>) and phosphates (PO<sub class='bodysubscript'>4</sub><sup class='bodySupscript'>3–</sup>). Rain washes these water-soluble nitrates and phosphates from cultivated land into surface waters where they promote the rapid growth of plants and algae, which speeds up the rate of <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. Eutrophication is a natural, usually gradual process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies. Human activities, however, can lead to cultural, or human induced, eutrophication, which can speed up this normally gradual process (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Schematic diagram of the different pathways of nutrient deposition into coastal waters and ensuing processes leading to eutrophication (algal blooms) and hypoxia.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Schematic diagram of the different pathways of nutrient deposition into coastal waters and ensuing processes leading to eutrophication (algal blooms) and hypoxia.

pageData.text:
Nutrient Sources by Hans W. Paerl is licensed under CC BY 2.0 available at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/48722974@N07/4856394679

Fertilizer runoff from lawns and farms, inadequately treated municipal wastewater, and poorly maintained septic systems all contribute to cultural <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. In agricultural areas with dense animal populations, animal waste adds nitrogen and phosphorus to surface waters as well. Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button>, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. When these organisms die, bacterial-mediated decay depletes water oxygen levels, kills sensitive aquatic organisms, and contributes to sediment buildup. If nitrogen is the limiting nutrient, such as in most brackish or marine waters, nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural eutrophication. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in freshwaters. Phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication in freshwaters.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Water from a cornfield flowing into a stream after a heavy rain.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Water from a cornfield flowing into a stream after a heavy rain.

pageData.text:
Agricultural runoff by Lynn Betts, USDA NRCS is licensed under CC BY 2.0 available at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/48722974@N07/4464667181

pageData.subTitle: Temperature
pageData.text: Temperature affects many chemical and biological processes. It modifies the solubility of oxygen in water, the rate of photosynthesis in aquatic plants, the metabolic rate of aquatic organisms, and the susceptibility of aquatic species to toxins and disease. Water temperature varies naturally with season and depth, but human activity also can affect temperature in significant ways. For example, heated water from surfaces—such as sunlit parking lots, roads, and sidewalks—and from industrial processes that use water as a coolant can flow into nearby creeks, streams, or rivers. This thermal pollution can destroy some types of aquatic life. Water loses heat very slowly, so thermally polluted water should be given significant dilution and time to cool before discharge into natural surface waters. Heated water also facilitates the rapid growth of some aquatic plants and algae, so thermal pollution can accelerate the rate of cultural <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Dissolved Oxygen
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Dissolved oxygen (DO)</button>, or the amount of oxygen in water, is essential for biotic diversity in a body of water. Much of the DO in water comes from the atmosphere. Atmospheric oxygen dissolves via diffusion into the water at the surface. Wind and waves stir the water, which dilutes the DO concentration at the surface by mixing, and subsequently increases the amount of oxygen that can dissolve at the surface. Another important source of oxygen in water is photosynthesis performed by aquatic plants and algae. Some of these aquatic photosynthetic organisms are rooted or attached to the streambed, whereas others are planktonic (live in the water column). The amount of photosynthetically generated DO in the water typically peaks in the afternoon when the sun reaches zenith and the most light penetrates the water. <button class='glossary-text'>Turbidity</button>, or murkiness resulting from a large number of particles in the water, can lower DO levels by reducing photosynthetic rates due to limited light penetration.
Many factors influence the amount of DO water can hold. Water with lower temperatures can contain higher oxygen concentrations.

Freshwater can hold more oxygen than saltwater. Another factor is altitude and atmospheric pressure; higher gas pressures result in higher gas concentrations dissolving into a liquid. Atmospheric pressure is greatest at sea level, so more oxygen dissolves into water at sea level than at higher elevations.

The amount of <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> in a body of water can vary greatly due to all these factors. After a DO measurement is taken from a water sample, a percent saturation value can be calculated by comparing the amount of oxygen the water contains at that moment with the maximum amount of oxygen that it could contain at that temperature.

Respiring organisms, such as animals and bacteria, significantly reduce DO levels as well. Bacteria in animal waste are a major concern in waterways that receive runoff from fields and pastures where livestock are kept. When oxygen becomes depleted in the water, it is said to be anoxic. Anoxic conditions cause marine organisms to suffocate.

pageData.subTitle: Coliform Bacteria
pageData.text: Coliform bacteria populate the intestinal tracts of warm-blooded animals and disperse throughout the environment along with fecal material. When an animal defecates, large numbers of coliform bacteria (called fecal coliforms) are present in the feces. Coliforms also can be released to the environment from a decomposing body. The presence of large numbers of coliforms in a water sample is a good indication that animal or human waste has polluted the water. Most coliforms do not cause disease, except for a few Escherichia coli strains. However, many pathogenic bacteria and parasites are spread through feces (e.g., those causing typhoid fever, hepatitis, gastroenteritis, and dysentery), and the presence of coliforms indicates that harmful pathogens might be present as well.

Determining the presence of coliforms in drinking water and in swimming areas is a very important tool for protecting public health. This is accomplished by collecting a water sample and inoculating some of the sample on <button class='glossary-text'>nutrient</button>-rich medium that supports coliform growth. After several days, the culture will show bacterial growth. This is the first step in determining the risk of animal or human waste contamination of a body of water. Additional tests can be performed to distinguish between total coliforms, which can have a number of sources, and fecal coliforms, which originate in animal and human intestines. There are potential risks associated with culturing pathogenic bacteria; therefore, this activity will only examine total coliforms.

pageData.subTitle: Total Suspended Solids
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Total suspended solids (TSS)</button> is a term used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated. Dissolved materials and <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> in natural water come from a variety of sources. Large concentrations of dissolved solids affect cellular nutrient transport, alter the taste of water, and interfere with industrial processes by fouling pipes and filters. Calcium and magnesium are two minerals commonly dissolved in water. A water-insoluble carbonate forms when aqueous calcium or magnesium hydrogen carbonate is heated. Industrial boilers reach high temperatures and generate solid deposits of magnesium carbonate and calcium carbonate, commonly called scale. These water-insoluble deposits reduce the efficiency of machines and are expensive to remove. TSS measurement requires the use of an analytical balance, which is not practical in a distance learning setting due to cost.

pageData.subTitle: Turbidity
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> test measures water clarity. Fine particles, such as eroded soil, and microscopic organisms, such as phytoplankton, contribute to water turbidity (Figure 3). Turbid waters clog fish gills, hinder disinfection processes, and carry entrapped pollutants downstream. Turbidity also blocks sunlight, which prevents photosynthesis below the surface and increases surface water temperature. Turbidity is measured in Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU). In this exercise, a modified turbidity tube will be used. A water sample is drained from the tube slowly, and the black-and-white pattern of a Secchi disk at the bottom of the tube becomes visible. At the point the pattern becomes visible, the sample volume is recorded and translated into NTU. If the pattern is visible when the tube is full, turbidity will be estimated using a saturation chart.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Three culture tubes with varying degrees of cloudiness.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Three culture tubes with varying degrees of cloudiness.

pageData.subTitle: Biochemical Oxygen Demand
pageData.text: Aerobic bacteria that decompose organic material require oxygen. In general, the more organic material there is in the water, the more oxygen demand will increase. When <button class='glossary-text'>biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)</button>, sometimes called biological oxygen demand, surpasses the amount of oxygen that can be added to the water, the water becomes anoxic. High BOD coupled with low <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> input causes water-quality deterioration, which can result in the death of many fish and animals.

An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased BOD is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically generated DO levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a natural process that can speed up the rate of eutrophication?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations.

pageData.question: Which of the following can cause an increase in biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eutrophication can cause an increase in BOD.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. For example, heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically-generated dissolved oxygen (DO) levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. For example, heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically-generated dissolved oxygen (DO) levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.subTitle: pH
pageData.text: Water contains hydrogen ions (H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>) and hydroxyl ions (OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>). The concentration of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ions determines the pH. If the concentration of H+ ions is higher than that of OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> ions, the pH is less than 7.0 and is considered acidic. Thus, the greater the concentration of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ions, the lower the pH will be. If the concentration of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ions is lower than that of OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> ions, the pH is greater than 7.0 and is considered alkaline (or basic). The pH scale is from 0 to 14 and is logarithmic; as the pH increases by one whole number, the H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> ion concentration decreases 10 times. For example, a pH change from 5 to 6 indicates a tenfold decrease in H+ concentration, and a pH change from 4 to 6 indicates a hundredfold decrease in H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> concentration.
Water rarely exists at the neutral pH of 7. Saltwater typically is slightly basic, with a pH of 8 or higher. Freshwater usually has a pH of 6.5, but this varies greatly between bodies of water.

Organic materials can affect the pH of water. Fallen leaves often contain tannic acid, which stains the water brown and reduces pH. Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water. Acid rain has a widespread effect on natural waterways in the eastern United States as well. Oxides of nitrogen and sulfur are released into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels; they mix with atmospheric water and form nitric and sulfuric acids. These acids are mixed with rainwater and delivered to natural waterways and soils. Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid. Rain is considered to be acidic if the pH is lower than 5.6.

Many freshwater organisms have adapted to a specific pH range. For some organisms, the optimum pH range is quite narrow. A sudden or drastic pH change will kill some of these organisms or reduce survival and reproduction, which disrupts food webs and the aquatic community. Lower pH levels also can release heavy metals from the surrounding bedrock into the water. Once dissolved, these metals can interfere with the uptake of <button class='glossary-text'>dissolved oxygen</button> by aquatic organisms.

pageData.question: What is the pH of normal rainwater?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid.

pageData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to reduce the pH of water in nature?

feedbackData.title: Feedback

Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water. pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 and alternate activity A of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, you will perform the coliform bacteria, DO, BOD, nitrate, pH and phosphate tests, according to the instructions in the LaMotte Test Kit. In alternate activity B, you will determine the altitude factor of your site. Next, you will determine the water temperature. Then, you will use the temperature and oxygen data to interpret the DO percent saturation chart and determine the dissolved oxygen percent saturation. Then proceed to alternate activity B.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 and alternate activity A of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, you will perform the coliform bacteria, DO, BOD, nitrate, pH and phosphate tests, according to the instructions in the LaMotte Test Kit. In alternate activity B, you will determine the altitude factor of your site. Next, you will determine the water temperature. Then, you will use the temperature and oxygen data to interpret the DO percent saturation chart and determine the dissolved oxygen percent saturation. Then proceed to alternate activity B.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for alternate activity B of this investigation. After completing alternate activity A, you will fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, you will remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, you will observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to each unobstructed disk and find the closest match to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. You will keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Finally, you will record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value.
pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for alternate activity B of this investigation. After completing alternate activity A, you will fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, you will remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, you will observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to each unobstructed disk and find the closest match to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. You will keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Finally, you will record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Quality of Surface Waters investigation (item number 652567) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron anytime you are dealing with chemicals, including the TesTabs<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>. Natural water samples can contain harmful contaminates and organisms. Wear your gloves and safety goggles during sample collection as well.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: 75% of the Earth’s surface is covered by water.  What percentage of that water is freshwater?

When rain washes water-soluble nitrates and phosphates from fertilizers off cultivated lands into surface waters, they promote rapid growth of plants and algae which speeds up the rate of which of the following?
Which of the following is NOT a common contributor of eutrophication?

options.text: fertilizer runoff from farms and lawns

assestmentData.question: Which of the following indicates that harmful pathogens may be present in water?
Which of the following is used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated?
Which statement is NOT true regarding the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) water can hold?

options.text: Saltwater can hold more oxygen than fresh water.
Water with lower temperatures can contain higher oxygen concentrations.
Higher gas pressures result in higher gas concentrations dissolving into liquid.
More oxygen dissolves into water at sea level than at higher elevations.
Photosynthetically generated dissolved oxygen in the water typically peaks in the afternoon when the sun reaches zenith and the most light penetrates the water.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following materials will you need to provide yourself to complete this investigation?
What ratio of bleach to water should you use to make the 10% bleach solution for this investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

typeBefore.text: Select your field sites for the following activities. This kit has enough test materials for 10 locations if the sample tubes are washed between samples.

pageData.text: Ideal water sources include shallow creeks, rivers, springs, or ponds. Locate several possible test sites on a map in case one of the sites isn’t ideal for sampling once you visit it in person. Also, make sure these areas are accessible to you. Sites located in county or state parks are accessible, but for visiting privately owned sites, you will need to acquire permission from landowners.

The <button class='glossary-text'>dissolved oxygen</button> and biological oxygen demand tests start at the field site and are completed after 5 days of incubation. The <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> and coliform tests can be started at the field site or within 2–3 hours of sample collection. It is common practice to use a cooler to transport samples, because they need to be kept cool and dark to prevent post-sampling photosynthesis from skewing test results.

Select an area to test based on the way the watershed flows. Choosing sites above and below the convergence of two waterways helps pinpoint the source of any pollution found in the samples. Prepare a map that marks the chosen sites. Each site can be identified with latitude and longitude using a GPS or GPS-enabled phone. If using the Google Maps app on an iOS smartphone, drop a pin at your desired location and scroll up from the menu bar at the bottom to see the coordinates. If using an Android smartphone, simply look in the search box at the top.

For accurate measurement of dissolved oxygen (biological water quality), determine the approximate altitude of the sample location. There are several websites that can help you identify the altitude of a pinned location (e.g., https://www.freemaptools.com/elevation-finder.htm and https://www.daftlogic.com/sandbox-google-maps-find-altitude.htm). There are also free apps for smartphones, such as “My Altitude” for iOS and “Get Altitude” for Android. You can also determine your altitude once you arrive at your destination if you are an iOS user. The elevation can be determined by using the “Compass” app on your smartphone. Make sure your location services are enabled for the “Compass” app. Then just open up the app, and the elevation will be seen at the bottom of your screen (along with the coordinates for your current location as well).
Read through the activities.

Obtain all materials that you need before starting the field trip. Make sure that you have the LaMotte® Dissolved Oxygen TesTabs®, the water-resistant sample comparison charts, printed copies of Table 1, the DO percent saturation chart, and Data Tables 1 and 2, a thermometer, the container that can hold 150 mL of water and its secure lid, aluminum foil, pipets, gloves, goggles, the permanent marker, and a cooler with ice if you will be transporting samples.

At the test site, collect each sample from a location that is representative of the waterway according to the activity instructions. Best results will be obtained if samples are collected from locations that are not close to stormwater drains and drainage ditches. For the most reliable results, water samples should be collected midstream. Water near the shore generally is not representative of an entire stream or river, because some runoff is highly concentrated and has not yet mixed with the main body of water.

In some situations (e.g., if the water is too deep), it may not be possible, feasible, or safe to obtain an ideal sample. If in doubt of the depth or safety of the water, DO NOT try to collect a sample from that location. Instead, collect a water sample from a location you are sure is safe.

In Activity 1, you will travel to your field test site and perform the tests for coliform bacteria, <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>BOD</button>, nitrate, pH, and phosphate, according to the instructions in the LaMotte test kit. You will use the lab manual directions rather than the test kit instructions to calculate the dissolved oxygen percent saturation and <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button>.

pages.title: Sample Collection and Water Quality Tests (3 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Sample Collection and Water Quality Tests (3 steps)

pageData.text:
Collect samples and test the water according to the instructions included with your LaMotte® Earth Force® Low-Cost Water Quality Monitoring Kit. You will perform tests for the following:
  • Coliform bacteria
  • and
  • Nitrate
  • pH
  • Phosphate

Record the results in Data Tables 1 and 2.For turbidity and dissolved oxygen percent saturation monitoring, please use the alternative tests provided in the “Alternative Activities” section of this manual instead of the procedures that are in the instructions included with your kit.

Note: The procedures for dissolved oxygen and biological oxygen demand are still done according to the instructions included with your kit. It is strictly the calculation for dissolved oxygen percent saturation that is to be followed as written in the “Alternative Activities” section of this manual instead of the instructions included with your kit.

Every time a color of a sample is compared to what is on one of the corresponding charts in this kit, take a photograph of your sample held up to the chart. Take a photograph of the vials at the end of the coliform bacteria tests as well.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In these activities, you will use the <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> scales and the altitude factor of your test site to determine the dissolved oxygen percent saturation of your water sample. You will also use a modified Secchi disk method to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> of the water sample in NTUs.

pages.title: Testing for Quality (13 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Calculating Dissolved Oxygen Percent Saturation (1 steps)

pageData.text:
Calculate percent saturation as follows:
  1. To obtain the corrected DO value, multiply the DO (ppm) value by the correction factor that corresponds to the altitude of the test site. Refer to Table 1, the “Altitude Correction Factor” table.

1. If you have not already, print out the DO percent saturation chart. Locate the corrected DO value on the “Oxygen, ppm” axis, and mark the point.
  2. Mark the temperature of the sample on the “Water temperature, °C” axis of the percent saturation chart.
  3. Using a straightedge, connect the two points. The intersection of the line with the “% Saturation” value is the corrected dissolved oxygen percent saturation level for the sample.
  4. Record the value in the “Dissolved Oxygen % Saturation” column in Data Table 1.
While wearing gloves and goggles, fill the graduated cylinder from your equipment kit to the 100 mL mark with water from your container of sample water.

Remove the cylinder from its base, and place it over the black-and-white pattern of the “0 NTU” <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> part of the sample comparison chart. This pattern, along with the “8 NTU” and “18 NTU” turbidity part of the chart, are acting as Secchi disks in this lab.

Look straight down through the water sample, and observe the “0 NTU” pattern through the water column. If you can see the pattern clearly, proceed to Step 3a. If you cannot see the pattern, proceed to Step 3b.
  1. If you can see the pattern at the bottom of the tube clearly, the water is too clear to be measured with the “0 NTU” pattern. You will have to estimate the turbidity by comparing the degree of turbidity from the “0 NTU” to the desaturated patterns of “8 NTU” or “18 NTU.” Look straight down into the cylinder over the black-and-white “8 NTU” pattern through the water column, and observe if the pattern of this desaturated pattern can be seen. If it is fuzzy and slightly visible (enough to make out the pattern), then “8 NTU” is the calculated turbidity (see Figure 4 for reference). However, if the pattern is clear, repeat the same procedure with the “18 NTU” pattern. If the “18 NTU” pattern appears fuzzy and slightly visible (enough to make out the pattern), then “18 NTU” is the calculated turbidity (see Figure 4 for reference). Record this value in Data Table 2.
  2. Pour off 5 mL of water. Look through the cylinder again. If you still cannot see the pattern, continue to pour off water in 5 mL increments until you can barely see the pattern. (It may appear fuzzy, but you will be able to make out the pattern. See Figure 4.)
    1. In Data Table 2, record the highest volume of water left in the graduated cylinder through which you can see the pattern.
    2. Estimate the NTU by comparing the volume to the volume on Table 2. Record the NTU in Data Table 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk

text:
1. The samples that were tested for coliform bacteria should be treated as potentially hazardous. Be sure to wear your gloves, goggles, and lab apron when disposing of this.
    1. Dispose of one vial at a time.
    2. Open one vial, and add approximately 1 mL of household bleach with a clean pipet.
    3. Immediately recap the vial. Repeat Steps 1b and 1c with the other vial.

pageData.text: Allow the vials to stand upright for 4 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Dispose of the vials in the trash without opening. DO NOT reuse the vials after coliform testing.

pageData.text: Dispose of other solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions. If tests were performed in the field, dump all solutions into a “waste container” to be dumped down a drain with the water running when you return home. Throw away all other materials from the materials kit in the household trash.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Sanitize the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.desc: Schematic diagram of the different pathways of nutrient deposition into coastal waters and ensuing processes leading to eutrophication (algal blooms) and hypoxia.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Schematic diagram of the different pathways of nutrient deposition into coastal waters and ensuing processes leading to eutrophication (algal blooms) and hypoxia.

pageData.content: Figure 2.  An example of run-off after rain
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Water from a cornfield flowing into a stream after a heavy rain.
Figure 3: Three culture tubes with varying degrees of cloudiness.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 and alternate activity A of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, you will perform the coliform bacteria, DO, BOD, nitrate, pH and phosphate tests, according to the instructions in the LaMotte Test Kit. In alternate activity B, you will determine the altitude factor of your site. Next, you will determine the water temperature. Then, you will use the temperature and oxygen data to interpret the DO percent saturation chart and determine the dissolved oxygen percent saturation. Then proceed to alternate activity B.

A map describing the procedural workflow for alternate activity B of this investigation. After completing alternate activity A, you will fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, you will remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, you will observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to each unobstructed disk and find the closest match to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. You will keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Finally, you will record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value.
Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk

data.title: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)
data.content: The amount of dissolved oxygen needed by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample

data.title: Dissolved oxygen (DO)
data.content: The amount of oxygen in water

data.title: Eutrophication
data.content: A natural process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies

data.title: Total suspended solids (TSS)
data.content: A term used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Murkiness resulting from particles suspended in water
